text.body:
itu paruvavaraviṉkaṇ vaṉpuṟai yetiraḻintu āṟṟāḷāyiṉāḷait tōḻi talaivaṉatu varavuṇarntu kūṟi āṟṟuvittatu.
33-1 vīṟucāṉ ñālattu viyalaṇi kāṇiya
33-2 yāṟukaṇ viḻittapōṟ kayanantik kaviṉpeṟa
33-3 maṇipurai vayaṅkaluṭ ṭuppeṟin tavaipōlap
33-4 piṇiviṭu murukkita ḻaṇikayat tutirntukat
33-5 tuṇikaya niḻaṉōkkit tutaipuṭaṉ vaṇṭārppa
33-6 maṇipōla varumpūḻttu maramellā malarvēyak
33-7 kātalar puṇarntavar kavavukkai nekiḻātu
33-8 tātaviḻ vēṉilō vantaṉṟu vārārnam
33-9 pōteḻi luṇkaṇ pulampa nīttavar;
33-10 eriyuru vuṟaḻa vilava malarap
33-11 poriyuru vuṟaḻap puṉkupū vutirap
33-12 putumalark kōṅkam poṉṉeṉat tātūḻppat
33-13 tamiyārp puṟatteṟin teḷḷi muṉiyavan
33-14 tārppatu pōlum poḻuteṇṇi yannalam
33-15 pōrppatu pōlum pacappu;
33-16 nontu, nakuvaṉapō ṉantiṉa kompu; naintuḷḷi
33-17 yukuvatu pōlumeṉ ṉeñcu; eḷḷit
33-18 tokupuṭa ṉāṭuva pōlumayil; kaiyi
33-19 lukuvaṉa pōlum vaḷai; eṉkaṇpō
33-20 likupaṟal vārum paruvattum vārār
33-21 mikuvatu pōlumin nōy;
33-22 narampiṉ ṟīṅkura ṉiṟukkuṅ kuḻalpō
33-23 liraṅkicai miñiṟoṭu tumpitā tūtat
33-24 tūtavar viṭārāyt tuṟappārko ṉōtaka
33-25 viruṅkuyi lālu marō;
33-26 eṉavāṅku,
33-27 purintunī eḷḷuṅ kuyilaiyu mavaraiyum pulavāti
33-28 nīlita ḻuṇkaṇāy neṟikūntal piṇiviṭa
33-29 nāḷvarai niṟuttuttāñ colliya poyyaṉṟi
33-30 mālaitāḻ viyaṉmārpar tuṉaitantār
33-31 kāluṟaḻ kaṭuntiṇṭēr kaṭaviṉar viraintē.
While the silk-cotton tree blossoms so that it resembles the colour of the flame,
while the Puṉku flowers drop so that they resemble the colour/form of parched rice,
while the Kōṅkam with new blossomed ripens gold-like pollen,
thinking of the time that seems to shout [at us],
having come hatefully, deriding [us] by attacking in the back those who are alone,
pallor seems to cover that beauty [of ours].
Achingly, the branches have flourished as if they were smiling. Painfully remembering
my heart seems to drop. Derisively
the peacocks seem to gather [and] dance. From [my] hands
the bangles seem to drop. In the season
that overflows with water, breaking like my eyes, he has not come.
It seems this pain is increasing.
While bees together with bumble bees feed on pollen, with lamenting sounds
like the flute that balances the sweet voice of the strings,
being one who does not send a messenger will he abandon us? Fit for pain
the dark koels sings, alas.”
That is to say,
“Don’t be vexed with the koel whom you twistingly deride and with him,
you with lotus-petalled kajal eyes. So that the braids of [your] curly tresses come loose
Unless it was a lie that he told when weighing the limit of the days [he would be away]
the one with a wide chest on which a garland hangs down is in a hurry,
driving fast the firm chariot fast like the wind.
